loans.name: Prosscovia

texts.en:
Prosscovia N. lives in the Kanyanya neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, two of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (her mother). Prosscovia lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees and rent.

Prosscovia has a business selling clothes. She has been in this business for 7 years, working 7 days each week. Prosscovia sells her products at the market, by means of retail. She has requested a loan of 1,000,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of secondhand clothes. The main business challenges for Prosscovia include transport and seasonality. Her goal and hope for her business is to start importing secondhand clothes.

loans.use: to buy more bales of secondhand clothes

loans.name: Merita

texts.en:
Merita A. is from the town of Banga. She is 54 years old, married and has 2 children aged 19 and 22. Merita owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Merita has been engaged in farming for over 30 years. She wishes to have her children finish college and have bright futures.

Merita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Merita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve it.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Amor

texts.en: Amor A. is from the village of Quiboro, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Amor owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, instant noodles and junk foods in the local community. Amor has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Amor joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amor is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Amor from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred B. is from the town of Banga. She is 35 years old, married and has 2 children ages 9 and 13. Mildred earns through farming and hog raising. She helps her husband plant and harvest rice crops and she also grows hogs for fattening. Mildred does her best to be a good wife and mother and says she only wants her family to be happy and healthy.

Mildred joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mildred is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase sacks of fertilizers and other farm supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Mildred from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn S. is from the village of Quiboro, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 28 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Marilyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and junk foods in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Marilyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marilyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. loans.name: Nena's Group

texts.en: Nena U. is from the village of La Paz, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 45 years old and is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Nena is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Nena owns and operates a business selling fish and vegetables to the local community. Nena has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP monthly from these activities. In 2008, Nena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Nena is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Nena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
Narcisa O. is from the village of Quiboro, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 51 years old. Narcisa is married and has 6]six adult-aged children. To make a living, Narcisa owns and operates a transportation service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing habal-habal (motorcycle transportation) services to local community members. Her husband drives the habal-habal. Narcisa has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Narcisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Narcisa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tools needed to provide the service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Narcisa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tools for her transportation business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary N. lives in the Kyebando Nsooba neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has three children, none of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (her grandchildren). Mary owns retail shop. She has been in this business for six years, and she works seven days out of every week. Mary has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more sugar, salt, soap, and cooking oil. She also generates additional income through rental rooms. The main business challenges for Mary include transport, thieves and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only. Mary lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, salt, soap, and cooking oil

loans.name: Marifel

texts.en:
Marifel L. is from the village of Tupsan, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 45 years old. Marifel is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Marifel owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying, dealing and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, lotions and detergents in the local community. Marifel has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marifel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marifel is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marifel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a single man who lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expense is transport costs.

He has been operating a barber shop for the past three years. In addition, he also runs a grocery business, selling retail, and at the market, which contributes to his other source of income. John faces the major challenges of seasonality and transportation in his business. He hopes to expand and sell cereals as wholesale in the future. 

With the 20,000 KES he wants to purchase sacks of beans, maize, rice and sugar. He decided to join Yehu to get loans and improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of beans, maize, rice and sugar

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius is a 28 year-old married man. He is blessed with two children, aged seven and four. He joined the Lion Head group in Faulu Kenya in order to access financial resources easily. So far, he has expanded his quarrying business through the support of Faulu Kenya, and is able to provide for his family in a better way. He hopes to provide his children with quality education in the future. He has requested a loan of 80,000 Kes to buy a motorbike, because he wants to start a motorbike transport business.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en: Marivic N.'s main source of income comes from providing repair services for watches for community members. She is 48 years old, married and has nine school-aged children. They are from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. Marivic has been in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Marivic joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Marivic is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed to provide her service. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tools needed to provide service

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert M. is 54 years old and married with five children. Their ages range from 24 to 34 years old, with two of them still attending school. He is a farmer from Nkubu town in central Kenya. He has run his business for 30 years and employs two workers. He sells products such as bananas, milk, avocados, and macadamia nuts to middlemen. He also sells coffee and tea to the Kenyan Tea Development Agency. In addition to running a farm, Robert is also a primary school teacher.

Robert has requested a loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 47,250 Kenyan shillings to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The proceeds from the loan will help him to educate his two children still in school. The biggest challenges for his business have been fluctuating input prices. However, in five years, Robert hopes to have expanded his farming business. He hopes to buy more dairy cows, construct a better zero-grazing shed, and to plant more coffee and tea.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow and insurance

loans.name: Remigio

texts.en:
Remigio R. is from the town of Banga. He is 60 years old, married and has ten children. Most of his children are adults and married already. Remigio is a farmer and he earns money by planting and harvesting rice crops. At his age, he is still strong enough to keep up with farming duties. Remigio still wants to help provide for his family. He also wants to be able to extend his support to his grandchildren.

Remigio joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Remigio is requesting a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase farm supplies such as fertilizers. This will be his first loan from CEVI. He plans to use additional revenue to support his family financially.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies such as fertilizers

loans.name: Cissy

texts.en:
Cissy K. has a retail shop. She also generates additional income through selling piped water. She is married and has four children, three of whom are in school. They live in the Ndeeba neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. Cissy lives in a home that she owns, and she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees and medication. Cissy has been in her business for 5 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. 

Cissy has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and cooking oil. The main business challenges for Cissy include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale and also to open up another shop in Kibuye.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and jerrycans of cooking oil

loans.name: Esterlina

texts.en:
Esterlina M. is from the village of Barangay Mauan, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 55 years old. Esterlina is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Esterlina owns & operates a business raising pigs for breeding. Esterlina has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Esterlina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Esterlina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 21,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Esterlina is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Esterlina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Pelita

texts.en:
Pelita T. is from the village of Tangaro, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 41 years old. Pelita is separated from her spouse and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Pelita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk foods in the local community. Pelita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Pelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Pelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Pelita is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Pelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph M. is a dairy farmer.  He has been farming for eight years and has employed two people.  He sells milk to the people of his local residence.  Besides farming, he is engaged in a transport business as a driver.  He is a hardworking man who hopes to be self-employed in the future. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has become determined in his business and hopes to prosper in the business. He has requested for 70,000 KES to buy a dairy cow and to renovate the cow shed.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and renovate the cow shed.

loans.name: Nelita

texts.en:
Nelita P. is from the village of Liong, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 38 years old. Nelita is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Nelita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk foods in the local community. Nelita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Nelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Nelita is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Nelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Akbar

texts.ru: Якубов Акбар проживает в районе Рудаки. Возраст, 33 года. Женат. Имеет четверых детей. Образование средне - специальное, шафер. По специальности проработал три года. Сейчас он занимается торговлей. Привозит в село Магмуруд картошку, где продает оптом. Кроме того в районе у него имеется продуктовый магазин. Торговлей занимается уже 5 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: Akbar Y. lives near the town of Rudaki, Tajikistan. He is 33 years old, married with four children. He has a secondary education specializing as a driver for three years. Currently, he's in sales and delivers potatoes to the village of Marmurud where he sells them at a wholesale price. He also has owned his own shop for five years. He is applying for a loan to increase sales for his business.

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Pinky

texts.en:
Pinky P. is from the village of Bonbon, in Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 32 years old, married, and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Pinky owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling ready-to-wear clothing & blankets in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Pinky joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. She is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. This will be Pinky’s 5th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: David

texts.en: David is a member of Faulu Kenya, in the Bidii Traders group.  Since he joined the group, he has become focused on developing his butchery, which currently has three employees.  He has twelve years of experience running the business and hopes to open a meat processing plant in five years.  He has requested 60, 000 KES to buy a freezer for preserving meat.

loans.use: to buy a freezer

loans.name: Cheruiyot

texts.en:
Cheruiyot  is a resident of Litein Town, in Rift Valley, and has been a dairy farmer for 4 years. He is also in the motorcycle transport business.  He earns income by producing milk and selling it locally.  He has two children aged 9 and 3.

Cheruiyot has applied for this loan of 33,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. He hopes this loan will improve his family’s income and standard of living. Animal feed remains his greatest challenge.  He wants to get better quality animals in the future and expand his land ownership.  He appreciates the impact of Juhudi Kilimo loans.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

texts.en:
Tessie L. is from the village of Benhaan in Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old. Tessie is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Tessie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, junk foods, instant noodles & biscuits in the local community. Tessie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Tessie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be Tessie's third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary S. lives in the Nabulagala neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 5 children, all of whom are in school.  Rosemary  has a retail shop. She has been in this business for less than one year and she works 7 days out of every week. Rose Mary has requested a loan of 900,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more sugar, salt, soap and cooking oil. She also generates additional income by selling charcoal. Rosemary's main business challenges include transportation, thieves and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and also to build her own business premises. Rosemary lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, salt, soap and cooking oil

To make a living, Milagros runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste & detergent powder in the local community. Milagros has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Milagros joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Milagros has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to buy and sell. loans.name: Tawapaneh Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of the “Tawapaneh” group from Waterloo, a small town near Freetown where “Shine on Sierra Leone” partnered with SMT to start a branch. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, also a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 2,800,000 for the entire group. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and, consequently, improve on their living conditions. 

Aminata K. is the leader of this group. The 40-year-old is married to a businessman and they have four children – two in primary school and two in secondary school.  Aminata sells cooked rice, fish, meat and vegetables. She has been a businesswoman for 15 years now.  With her share of this loan, she will buy gallons of palm oil, bags of rice, fish, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), etc. in large quantity.

loans.use: To buy gallons of palm oil, bags of rice, fish, margi, etc. in large quantity

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en: Anthony is a father of two.  For a living, he does quarrying.  He has managed to grow his business through Faulu Kenya because he gets financial support.  He is also skilled in masonry and earns extra income from it.  He hopes to provide for his children better living standards in the future.  For this reason, he works hard in his business.  He has requested for 50, 000 Kenyan shillings to buy a piece of land where he can quarry stones.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily M. is 36 years old and has a child aged 16 years who is currently attending school. She lives in Eldoret town, located in western Kenya.

She has been in the farming business for 11 years and also sells poultry and milk. Emily is requesting a loan of 36,400 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase a dairy cow.

In five years, she hopes to have expanded her business by purchasing four more dairy cows. The expected profits will be used to help repay the loan and pay her child's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda is a resident of Kitale Town in Western Kenya.She has two children, aged 20 and 11, and both are attending school. She has been doing mixed farming for eight years, producing milk, wheat and maize, and selling locally.

She has applied for this loan of 31,200 Kenyan shillings (KES) to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She believes the income generated will cater to the children's education. She hopes to supply milk supply on a large scale, though animal diseases remain her challenge. She had acquired a loan of 30,000 KES previously and paid it back.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine L. lives in the Busega neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has five children, four of whom are in school.  Catherine has a business of food vending. She has been in this business for 20 years and she works seven days out of every week. Catherine sells her products in a shop on a retail basis.    

Catherine has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO. She will use it to buy more bags of cassava and sweet potatoes and bunches of bananas. She also generates additional income through selling charcoal. 

The main business challenges for Catherine include transport and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling on a wholesale basis only and to educate her children up to university. 

Catherine lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sweet potatoes and cassava and bunches of bananas

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda is a widowed lady with three children who are in school. She has been rearing chickens for 12 years. In her business, she employs casual laborers when she has a lot of work in her poultry house. She also sells clothes to supplement her family’s income.  

She joined Faulu Kenya under the Faida Jamii group so as to access loans easily. She has requested 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy chicken feed and chicks.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed and chicks

loans.name: Baigalmaa

texts.en:
Baigalmaa B. is a 30 year old who lives with her husband and three sons in Hovd province, Mongolia. She and her family live in an apartment. Her oldest son is in kindergarten while her youngest infant twin sons stay at home. 

Baigalmaa operates a retail clothing business in her town. At first, she started to work as a salesperson in her sibling's business by selling a variety of clothing items in 2008. Since 2009, she has been operating her own retail clothing business using earnings from her livestock. 

For the future, she plans to purchase her own workplace and increase her working capital. Baigalmaa is requesting a 500,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase more clothes to sell for the upcoming winter season.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes

loans.name: God Is Great Ii Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “God is Great II” group from Waterloo, a small town in western Sierra Leone where “Shine on Sierra Leone” partnered with SMT to start a branch.  They are petty businesspeople who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to seek a loan of SLL 1,000,000 for each in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and consequently, improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Mohamed F.. Mohamed was born in the village of Masingbi 34 years ago. He is married and has one child. His wife is a trader and his child is attending primary school. Mohamed has been a businessman for many years now. He sells used tires. With his share of this loan, he will buy 50 used tires to add to his current ones.

loans.use: To buy used tires to add to his current ones

loans.name: Dolgorsuren

texts.en: Dolgorsuren J. is 46 years old and lives with her husband and two children in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest son attends university while her youngest daughter attends a secondary school. Dolgorsuren operates a consumer-goods retailing business. She sells a variety of small consumer goods that are imported from Erlian, China. She started her business in 2000 and has built a stable and successful operation. Since then, she has found success in her business and bought a grocery trading shop next to her home. After years of successful operation, she has managed to increase her family's standard of living greatly. Dolgorsuren hopes to expand her business and increase her product line by selling clothes. She is requesting a 500,000 Mongolian tugriks loan in order to purchase a variety of products to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of products

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius is a married man with one child who is still too young for school. He lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and rent bills. He operates a clothes-selling business, selling leso (also known as khangas, or traditional African cloth) and shoes. He sells from home to neighbors and passersby. Julius faces a major challenge in delayed payments by creditors. He hopes that someday he will establish a boutique shop. With the 15,000 Kenyan shillings, he wants to purchase a bale of lesos and shoes for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase a bale of Lesos (also known as khangas, or traditional African cloth) and shoes for resale

loans.name: Ichinhorloo

texts.en:
Ichinhorloo Y. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live together in a winter house with a fence. Her two sons, ages 13 and 16, both attend a local secondary school while her husband operates a public-transportation business using his own car. 

Ichinhorloo operates a clothing and consumer-good trading business out of a stall at the local market in her town. Her business is located in a popular spot of the market and attracts many customers. She started her clothes-selling business in 1998 and has built a stable operation. After many years of owning this business, she has gained significant experience as a trader. She makes her procurement twice a month. In addition, she owns a shop next to her home to supplement her earnings. 

Ichinhorloo is a modest, diligent and hardworking person and says, "I am planning to procure more products that can satisfy my customers' needs in order to sell in my stall and increase my sales income." 

She is requesting a 2,500,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase transportation for milk produced on the farm

loans.name: Munhtuya

texts.en: Munhtuya B. is 24 years old and lives with her husband and 2-year-old daughter in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in the Dragon of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband operates a transportation business using his own car to support the family. Munhtuya operates a consumer-goods business at a local market in the city. She started her retail trading business in 2009 and has found success within a short period. Her monthly business profits have reached 350,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) and her earnings have enabled her to buy electronic appliances for her family as well as contribute money to purchase a car for her husband. Munhtuya works hard to grow her business and hopes to expand in the near future. She has used her business earnings to solve her family's problem, therefore her working capital has decreased. She is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to increase her product amount in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy used clothing for resale

loans.name: Hope To God Ii Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Hope To God II” group. These are small-scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in order to invest in their businesses. 

Adama K. is the leader of this group. Adama was born in Gbintin village. She is 29 years old. Adama is married to a businessman and they have three children: two in primary school and one in secondary school. Adama sells palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), nut oil (lesser in value to palm-oil), garri (fast food made out of cassava roots), etc. With the help of this loan, Adama will buy palm oil, nut oil, garri, etc. at wholesale to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy palm oil, nut oil, garri, etc. at wholesale to add to her business

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 34 years old and is a father of 6, aged between 14 and 2.  He is a resident of Kitale Town in Western Kenya.  He has been doing mixed farming, producing milk, eggs, and tomatoes.  All his products are sold locally.  He has been in farming for 8 years.

He has requested this loan of 31,200 KES to purchase a dairy cow and had acquired one previously.  He hopes the loan will make life better for the family by improving his income.  He plans to have 5 dairy cows in 5 years time.

George has no other source of income.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Ulamsuren

texts.en:
Ulamsuren T. is 61 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in their own ger -- a traditional housing tent, in Hovd province, western Mongolia. 

He was a driver and used to work in the government organization till 2005. Since then, he has been operating a car repair and welding service in his home. After years of successful operation, he has built his business to a consistent level with a stable operation. His earnings have enabled him to not only pay his child's tuition fees but also invest money for his son who lives on his own. 

For the future, Ulamsuren hopes to build a house in his yard with his business profits. He is a modest and hardworking man. He needs more fund to improve his welding equipment as well as purchase more raw materials for his business. He is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan to purchase the  necessary materials and equipment for his car repair and welding service business.

loans.use: To purchase necessary materials and equipment

loans.name: Evelynda

texts.en:
Evelynda C. is a simple woman, a responsible mother, and a loving wife to Clemente C. Sr. from Maradiona, Belison, Antique, Philippines. They are blessed with two children: Clairyvell 3 years old, and Christian Dave 5 months old. 

Like other women, she has dreams of a good future for her family, and that dream pushed her to join ASHI because she believes that the institution could help her achieve those dreams.

In 2009, she decided to join ASHI and got a first loan amounting to Php. 5000.00, which she had successfully fully paid.

At present she is requesting Php 3,000.00.  This amount will be use as a capital to continue her business variety store. She is only proposing a small amount because according to her she still has a baby so she can’t give full attention to her business. But while she has to stay in their house, she wants to earn an income so that she could help support the needs of the family.

loans.use: Working capital for store

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah B. lives in the Kawempe Bubajwe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has  4 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members.  

Sarah has a business of owning a restaurant. She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week.  Sarah sells her products from home, by means of retail. 

Sarah has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of cassava, sweet potatoes, bunches of bananas, and crates of soda.  She also generates additional income through selling firewood.  

The main business challenges for Sarah include transport and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked hotel.  

Sarah lives in a home that she owns.  She has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include feeding the family, school fees, and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bananas, sweet potatoes, rice, soda and passion fruits

loans.name: Samura

texts.en:
This is 46-year-old Samura. He is married and has 3 children ages 9, 7, and 3. In 2005, Samura established his used clothing business. He began his business because it enabled him to support his family and his children's education. Working 4 days a week and 6 hours a day, he earns about Le 1200000 every month. 

He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000 in order to buy more clothes. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 560,000. In the future, Samura plans to buy a vehicle and to establish a savings account. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more used clothing for resale

loans.name: Quick Action Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “Quick Action” group. They are small-scale businesswomen in the small town of Waterloo, near Freetwon. This will be their first loan from SMT/Kiva lenders.  With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit. 

Wulamatu K. is the leader of this group. Wulamatu was born in the village of Foredugu. She is 44 years of age and married with six children who are all grown-up and living on their own. Wulamatu sells dishes, rubber bowls, buckets, etc. She has been a businesswoman for 30 years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items in large quantity to add to her business.

loans.use: To buys dishes, rubber bowls, buckets, etc. in large quantity to add to her business

loans.name: Hyline

texts.en:
Hyline is 27 years old and has been doing mixed farming for 6 years, producing milk, vegetables, and maize. She has 2 children.

She has applied for this loan of  31,200 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow.  She had acquired the first loan for a similar amount.  She hopes the loan will be able to improve her family's standard of living through the education of the children.  She plans to have 3 dairy cows and a poshomill (for crushing maize and other cereals)

The main challenge remains water shortage in the dry seasons.  She is very appreciative of the first loan benefits.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Bauzhar

texts.en:
Bauzhar K. lives in the Kyrgyz southern city of Osh. She is 51 and married. Bauzhar is the mother of three children: two daughters who live on  their own, and one son of school age. 

After graduating from an industrial institute, she worked at the local cotton plant.  In 1998, in order to find an additional means of subsistence for her family, Bauzhar decided to begin her sales business. 

Being a very persistent person, she concentrated all her efforts and achieved success. Bauzhar managed to obtain a selling place at the local market, which had a wide assortment of home rubber sheets.  Unfortunately, in June 2010, when violent clashes caused by the deposed political regime broke out in the city of Osh, Bauzhar lost her business, which was robbed and looted. 

However, Bauzhar isn't giving up and is ready to resume her lost business and continue to work. For this reason, Bauzhar is applying for a loan of 100,000 KGS, which she needs to restart her activity. She plans to purchase more goods to resell at the local market. With the revenues, Bauzhar wants to give a good education to her son.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase goods for resale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy trousers and shirts to sell in the local market

loans.name: Drusira

texts.en:
Drusira is a resident of Kitale Town in Western Kenya and has been doing mixed farming for over 8 years. She produces milk, eggs, and vegetables, all of which are sold locally.

She has applied for a loan of 31,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow.   She says the loan will improve her milk production,  hence income.  She plans to own three cows and a water tank.

Animal feed shortage and diseases remain her greatest challenge.  She is focused on repaying the loan to apply for the second one.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet N. lives in the  Kawempe Bubajwe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has 3 children, all of whom are in school.  Janethas a business of charcoal selling.  She has been in this business for 3 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Janet sells her products at the market, by means of retail. 

Janet has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal.    .

The main business challenges for Janet include transport and the rainy season.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van.  Janetlives in a home that she rents.  She has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include feeding the family , rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy charcoal for resale

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a father of 3, aged between 9 and 4 years.  He has been doing dairy farming for over 5 years.  His produce of milk is sold to the local market.  He has employed two farmhands.

He requested the loan of 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo in order to venture into poultry farming.  He had acquired a loan of 40,000 KES previously for a dairy purpose.  He plans to expand his production level and start a mini-processing plant specifically for cheese and ghee.  He says the income generated from poultry is solely planned for his children's education.

His challenge however remains the marketing of produce.  He is advocating for the introduction of educational loans by Juhudi Kilimo.

loans.use: To start poultry business

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon K., 41, sells old tires at Kayole Estate in Nairobi. Kayole is near a slum called Soweto, and Simon's customers are low class people. He is married to Beatrice Munee who is a dressmaker and together they have two daughters: Linet (11), and Cynthia (2). He has been running this business for 13 years, and he gets a monthly profit Kshs 20,000 and his wife also supports him financially.

He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by existing clients. This will be his second loan, and he plans to use the Kshs 40,000 to buy more old tires for resale. If the loan boosts the business, he will open another shop for the same business and employ someone to help him.

In the future, Simon who describes himself as hardworking and trustworthy hopes to open a vehicle spare parts shop and provide higher education to his children.

loans.use: To increase stock of tires for sale

loans.name: Nepatao Ole

texts.en:
Nepatao Ole K., 34, is married to Koitoi K. and is a father of two school going children. Nepatao is a farmer and he does wheat farming on his own piece of land. He has been involved in farming for the last six years.

He learned about KADET through a marketing campaign done by KADET staff in his area of residence. This will be his second loan which he plans to spend on his twenty acres of land by preparing the land for the next planting season and buying farm inputs. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to re-invest in the farm and plant more acres of wheat.

Nepatao hopes to become a large scale farmer in wheat and buy a bigger piece of land.

loans.use: to prepare his land for the next planting season and buy farm inputs

loans.name: Rukiya

texts.en:
Rukiya is a widowed woman with five children, one of whom attend school while four graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She operates a natural soft drink making business, selling from home to her neighbours and passers-by. Rukiya faces a major challenge of seasonality. During the rainy winter season, the demand for soft drinks is lower compared to the hot summer season, when the demand rises. She hopes to own a parlour in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000, she wants to purchase pumps to do plumbing in the home. She decided to join Yehu, because it provides sustainable financial services.

loans.use: To purchase pumps for home plumbing

loans.name: Waldir

texts.es:
El   Sr. Waldir   es casado tiene   2  hijos,  todos   en edad escolar.
El   se dedica a la venta de Zapatos Usados,  en su domicilio, cuya venta le genera  un buen ingreso.

Con la ayuda de su esposa  están  saliendo adelante con mucho sacrificio y dedicación.
Hoy día el es una microempresario exitoso con  mucha  clientela, debido a su buen trato.
Ha demostrado ser una persona responsable y honesta en sus compromisos, y solicita el préstamo para la compra de calzados.
texts.en:
Sr. Waldir is married and has 2 school-aged children.  He operates a business in his house, selling used shoes.  The business provides him with a good income.

Waldir is managing to forge ahead with help from his wife and much sacrifice and dedication.  He is now a successful micro-entreprenuer who, thanks to the good deals he offers, has a large customer base.  He has shown himself to be honest and responsible in his dealings and he is applying for this loan to stock his business.

loans.use: Buy merchandise to resell.

loans.name: Caleb

texts.en:
Caleb is a resident and a farmer in Nyamira Town in Western Kenya, producing tea, bananas, maize, tomatoes, and cabbages for the last 7 years.  His produce are always sold locally.

He has requested this loan of 45,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow.  He believes his business can grow and enable him to venture into the public transport business in the future.  He also says the loan will improve his income and also help in educating his child with the income generated.

Caleb's main challenge remains the poor road network and drought.  He appreciates the loan advances from the company.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Benedetta

texts.en:
Benedetta M., 28, runs a general shop, where she mostly sells cereals, at Matuu town. She is married to Mutuku Mutua who is a farmer. She has been running this business for a period of 3 years and her monthly profit is Kshs 10,000.

She was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of Tala office. This will be her third loan, and she plans to use the loan to increase stocks of maize, beans, and green gram for sale. If the loan boosts the business, she will save toward expanding her business.

Benedetta describes herself as a hardworking woman who dreams of growing her business into a very big shop one day.

loans.use: To increase stocks of maize, beans, and green grams

loans.name: Suyumkan

texts.en:
Suyumkan K. is an attentive mother of three children in a tight-knit family. They live in Keper-Arik village, in the northern part of Kyrgyzstan. 

After graduating from college, she worked as a laboratory assistant at a local plant. When Suyumkan was 20, she got married and soon became the mother of her beloved children. Her husband worked at the sugar mill but his wage was too low to cover all their family’s expenses. In order to support her family, Suyumkan decided to engage in livestock breeding. She bought one milk cow and one bull-calf and managed to develop a farm with four bull-calves and cows. 

In 2006, using the revenues from selling most of the cattle, Suyumkan was able to buy a car and pay for her son‘s education. Now Suyumkan plans to use this loan of 60,000 Kyrgyz Soms to broaden her number of cattle for fattening and reselling. In the future, Suyumkan dreams to open a small shop with meat and milk products.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Hiram Mwingi

texts.en:
Hiram Mwingi is 46 years old and married to Susan, who helps with the farm and contributes to the family income. They have two dependent children. Hiram runs a grocery shop at Kiarutura, which has been in existence for the last two years and from which he gets an income of 10,000 Kenyan shillings a month.

He is taking his third loan with KADET, after successfully repaying his previous loans. He wants to use the loan to buy more onions, tomatoes, pineapples and sugar. 

He hopes to own a wholesale shop in the future and to be able to increase his income, allowing him to improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: To buy onions, tomatoes, pineaples and sugar

loans.name: Julius Kamau

texts.en:
Julius is 57 years old and married to Hellen, with whom he has five children. Hellen helps with the farm, which adds to the family's income. Julius operates a public transport business, which has been running for one year.

He is taking his first loan with KADET. He has never borrowed from a microfinance institution before. He intends to use the loan to repair his vehicle to be able to carry passengers. 

He hopes to improve the living standards of his family and expand his transport business.

loans.use: To repair and and carry out maintainance work on his vehicle

loans.name: Ikayo

texts.en:
Ikayo N., 44, is a livestock trader. He is married to Mavania, 40, who is a farmer. Together they have five children aged two, seven, 10, 12 and 14. He lives at Enkaroni in Kajiado and sells his livestock in the nearby Bissil market. He has been running his livestock trading business for two years, and his monthly profit is 10,000 KES. Bissil is a very busy market with a large population, so Ikayo’s livestock are bought at good prices and he uses the profit to take care of his family and save for his children’s education.

Ikayo learned about KADET through the World Vision area development program. He has applied for a loan, which he intends to use to buy livestock for trading. If the loan boosts the business, Ikayo intends to start selling meat wholesale, which will give him more profit.

Ikayo wants to become a big businessman is describes himself as very enterprising.

loans.use: To buy livestock for trading

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Abas

texts.en:
This is 36-year-old Abas.  He is married and has 3 children aged 16, 14 and 8 years. In 2005, Abass established his cosmetics and toiletries business. He began his business because he was unable to go further in school so he decided to go into business. Working 7 days a week and 11 hours a day, he earns about 1,037,000 SLL every month from this business. 

He needs a loan of 4,500,000 SLL. Abas requires this loan in order to buy more cosmetics and toiletries. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 259,250 SLL. In the future, Abas hopes to open another cosmetics shop for his wife.  He owned the biggest cosmetics shop in his locality. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics and toiletries

loans.name: Kanini

texts.en:
Kanini J. is a 32-year-old poultry farmer in Mtwapa. She is married to Abdalla Omari, and they are blessed with two children. She has been in the poultry farming business for the past six years and has a steady income.

She has applied for her second loan with KADET, and she plans to purchase chickens and feed. She will use the anticipated profits to expand her business. 

Her hopes in the future is to own another plot where she can expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase chickens and feed

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 40 years old and married to Monica Njeri. They have three children. Monica helps with the farm, which they have been managing for the past two years. They normally sell the produce and farm animals, and from this he and his family get 6,000 Kenyan shillings a month as income. 

This is his first loan with KADET. He has never borrowed from any other microfinance institution before. He intends to buy seedlings, fertilizers and animal feed. 

He hopes to be a leading dairy and crop farmer in the future, which will improve his standard of living.

loans.use: To buy seedlings, fertilizer and animal feeds

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima M. K. is a 38-year-old widow and a mother of four children. She has been operating a clothing business for the last 10 years and from this business she has been able to provide for the basic needs for herself and her family.

This is her second loan with KADET after successfully servicing her first loan well. She plans to use this money to purchase ladies accessories (belts, shoes, earrings). The anticipated profits will be used to re-stock her business.

She hopes to become a successful business lady.

loans.use: to purchase ladies accessories for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy welding materials

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary N. K. is a 54-year-old lady from Mtopanga. She is married and supports her family. She has been working in the food business selling cooked food to her customers in the market like mixed vegetables, rice, stew and others for the past 21 years with great success.

She joined KADET the other day and has applied for her first loan which she wants to use to purchase more stocks for her business like rice, beans, and vegetables. She plans to use the anticipated profits to start another business.

She hopes to purchase more stock for the business and live happily.

loans.use: To purcchase more stock  for business

loans.name: Harutyun

texts.en:
Harutyun P. is 48 years old and lives in the city of Vanadzor. He is married with three children — two daughters and a son. One of his daughters is already married and lives separately; the second daughter is a student studying in Yerevan. His son is in school and recently became the Armenian champion of freestyle wrestling. Harutyun is very proud of his son's achievements. 

For about 15 years Harutyun has been engaged in trading men and women clothing and sleepwear at the Vanadzor clothes fair. His wife stays at home and keeps the house.
 
Harutyun needs a 1,000,000 AMD loan to buy men's jackets for his business.  This is Harutyun’s second loan from Kiva and 14th loan from Nor Horizon.

loans.use: To buy jackets for resale

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson is a resident of Kitale Town in Western Kenya, and has been doing dairy farming for 4 years.  He has a family of 3.

He has applied for a loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow.  He says the loan and purchase of a dairy cow will make his dairy business more profitable.  He adds that the milk will also be consumed by the family as well as sold to pay for the education of the children.  He wants to venture into the wholesale dairy business.

He says his challenge remains animal diseases.  He appreciates the partnership with Juhudi Kilimo.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher MwaT. T. is a 38-year-old electrician and retail shop owner in Bakarani Mombasa. He is married to Kache Jefwa, who contributes to the family’s total income. They are blessed with two children. He has been in this businesses for the past year and has a steady income.

With this, his first loan from KADET, he wants to purchase more electrical gadgets for services in his shop and use the anticipated profit to renovate his shop.

In the future he hopes to become very successful in life.

loans.use: To purchase electrical gadgets

loans.name: Tomas

texts.es:
El Señor Tomas I. es cliente recurrente de la Fundación Paraguaya, se inicio en el año 2006, está acompañado con la Señora Lucia Leguizamón con quien no tiene hijos, poseen una despensa en su domicilio que está ubicado en el Barrio San Rafael de Ciudad del Este.
También cabe mencionar que posee un pequeño taller dedicado a la tapicería y trabajos de reparación de muebles.
Todos los créditos retirados por el mencionado poseen un histórico impecable  de pago, agradece el crecimiento laboral que obtuvo con nuestra Institución.
Se tratan de personas trabajadoras y con espíritu de superación, y solicita el préstamo para la compra de mercaderías para su negocio como, azúcar, fideos, arroz, carne, panificados.
texts.en:
Tomas is a recurring client of the Fundacion Paraguaya (Paraguayan Foundation).  He began in the year 2006.  His partner is Lucia and they have no children.  He has a store in his house, which is located in the San Rafael Barrio of Ciudad del Este.  It is also worth mentioning that he has a small shop dedicated to upholstery and furniture repair. 

All the loans repaid by Tomas have an impeccable payment history and he is grateful for the growing collaboration with our Institution.

These are hard-working people who have the spirit to get ahead, and Tomas requests the loan to purchase merchandise for his business, such as sugar, beans, rice, meat, and backed goods.

loans.use: TO BUY SUGAR, BEANS, RICE, MEAT, AND BAKED GOODS TO SELL

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 33 years old and lives in the town of Litein in western Kenya. She is married and has seven children ranging in age from 12 to 1. She has been in the farming business for ten years and sells products such as tea, bananas, and milk. 

Sarah has requested a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase a a dairy cow. With the expected increase in income, she hopes to be able to afford school fees for her children.

Although she faces the challenge of not having a constant water supply, in five years she hopes to have improved her business by purchasing more dairy cows of better quality.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu O. is a 32-year-old clothes and shoes dealer in Mtwapa, Mombasa. She is divorced but supports three children and she has been in this business for the last four years with an income that is able to take care of and provide for her family.

With this, her first loan from KADET, she hopes to purchase bales of clothes for resale and use the anticipated profits to educate her children and expand her business.

In the future, she hopes to own a big store and sells more clothes and shoes.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more local foodstuffs

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul M., aged 36, is a dealer in the scrap metal business. He buys pieces of used and worn out metals and sells them in bulk. His business is located along Magadi Road, which is busy and he gets many customers. 

He is married to Mercy Wangari and together they have a daughter and son who are both in primary school. He has been running this business for a period of 3 years and his monthly income is Kshs 10,000.

He was introduced to KADET by KADET existing customers. He has applied for his second loan with KADET LTD and he plans to increase his stock of scrap metal for resale. If the loan boosts the business, Paul will buy a piece of land.

Rental houses have become a good business in Kenya and so Paul dreams that one day he will build many rental houses and become a landlord. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To buy scrap metal to sell

loans.name: Silas Ngari

texts.en:
Silas is 39 years old and married to Milka, who is a housewife. They have been blessed with four young children. Silas runs a cereals shop which has been in existence for the past two years with an income of 15,000 Kenya shillings a month.

This is his first loan with Kadet which he wants to use to buy 20 bags of maize and beans. He has never borrowed from another MFI before. 

He hopes to educate his children to the highest level and expand his business.

loans.use: To buy 20 bags of maize and beans

loans.name: Petrosyan

texts.en: P. Petrosyan lives in Sasnashen village in the Aragatsotn region, Armenia. He is married with 2 children. The main family income comes from land cultivating and farming, in which he has been engaged for a long time as the only source of improving his living standards. P. has applied to SEF for a loan to begin autumn crops and acquire cattle food.

loans.use: To begin autumn crops and buy cattle food

loans.name: Sergio

texts.es:
El  Sr Sergio   es casado se dedica a la reparación de autos y chapería,  cuyo trabajo  le genera  un buen ingreso.

Con la ayuda de su esposa  e hijos  están  saliendo adelante con esmero y dedicación.
Hoy día tiene una clientela formada quienes se encuentran muy satisfechos con el servicio que reciben de él.
Es una persona muy responsable con sus compromisos y con ansias de progreso, por lo se le debe dar el merecido apoyo y solicita el préstamo para la compra de algunas herramientas que el necesita en taller.
texts.en: Mr. Sergio is married and works in auto and body repair, which generates a good income. With the help of his wife and children they are moving forward with care and dedication. Today, he has a clientele who are very satisfied with the service they receive from him. He is very responsible with his commitments and his forward progress, so one must give due support as he is seeking a loan for the purchase of some tools that he needs for his shop.

loans.use: Purchase tools to use in the workshop.

loans.name: Mariatu

texts.en:
This is Mariatu, who is 46 years old.  She is married and has 5 children, aged 22, 18, 16, 9, and 4.  She also has 4 additional dependents.

In 1980, Mariatu established her local foodstuffs, cooked rice, and palm oil business.  She started her business in order to generate enough income to help her husband provide a livelihood for their family.  Working 7 days a week, 10 hours a day, she earns about 1,118,600 Sierra Leone leones (SLL) per month from her business.

Mariatu has a very good loan repayment history.  She needs a loan of 3,000,000 SLL in order to buy more foodstuffs.  She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 380,324 SLL.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more local foodstuffs

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William O. is a farmer and resident of the town of Nyamira in western Kenya.  He has been practicing mixed farming for the last 10 years.  He produces milk, tea, maize, beans, and chicken that he sells locally.  He has two temporary employees.

William earns a salary of 7,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) per month.  He has requested a loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow.  The loan will improve his family's earnings.

William hopes to expand his farm and rear more sheep.  His only challenge is a lack of farm inputs due to their high cost.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Nelson Kampus

texts.en:
Nelson Kampus L. is 19 years old. He is married to Noonkuta L. and he is a father of one child aged one year. Nelson is a wheat farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land which he has been doing for the last five years.
  
Nelson learned about KADET from a member of a group that is registered with KADET.  This will be his first loan. He is planning to prepare land for the next planting season. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to reinvest in the farm and plant more acres of wheat.

His hope and dream is to become a large scale farmer in wheat and buy a bigger piece of land.

loans.use: To prepare land for the next planting season

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry is a resident of Kitale Town in western Kenya. He has three children and has been doing mixed farming for 10 years, producing maize, groundnuts, millet and bananas to sell to the local market.

He has applied for this loan of 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says the proceeds will help him pay for the education of his children. He plans to have four dairy cows in five years time.

His major challenge remains poor prices while production costs remain very high.He recommends more diversification in Juhudi Kilimo loan products.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: John Kabare

texts.en:
John Kabari K. is 40 years old. He is married to Gladys Wangare and is a father of two children, aged two and a half and four years. John is a businessman and he deals with electrical services. He has been in the business for the past ten years.
  
John learned about KADET from a member of a group within his locality. This will be his fifth loan and he is planning to buy more electrical items to expand his electrical business. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to reinvest in the business and build a house for his family.

His dream is to become successful in his business and be known country-wide.

loans.use: To buy electrical items to expand business

loans.name: Policalo

texts.en:
Policalo M. is a resident and farmer in the town of Nkubu in eastern Kenya.  He produces bananas, coffee, beans, maize, and milk that he sells locally.  He has been practicing mixed farming for the last two years.  He also runs a shop and earns additional income from his motorbike.  He has two employees on a temporary basis.

Policalo has requested a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to develop a banana plantation and buy water pipes.  He hopes to buy four dairy cows and to have a good banana plantation with good returns.  His main challenges are unreliable labor, unpredictable weather conditions, and diseases.

loans.use: To develop a banana plantation

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina N. is married and lives with her husband, 2 student children, and her in-laws. A teacher in the past, since 2002 Marina has been trading women’s clothing and underwear from a rented shop in one of the city’s markets. 

In the past, Marina used to travel to the neighbouring countries to purchase inventory. Now, Marina puts her orders through other traders so she can spend more time managing the shop.  Currently Marina requires new stock for the shop. With a good credit history behind her, to help her finance the inventory order, Marina has applied to SEF International for a loan.

loans.use: To purchase clothes inventory

loans.name: Fatu

texts.en:
This is 53-year-old Fatu. She is married and has three children. She has three additional dependents who live with her because they are her relatives. 

In 1980, Fatu established her clothing business. She began her business because she wanted to have a means of generating income to help her husband support the home. 

Working six days a week and nine hours a day, Fatu earns about 1,126,000 Sierra Leone leones (SLL) every month from this business. She needs a loan of 3,000,000 SLL to buy more clothing. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 337,800 SLL. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more clothing for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cotton piqué, satiny cotton, silk, gabardine, poplin in different colors

loans.name: Karo

texts.en: Karo G. lives with his wife and 3 children. The family’s main income comes from cattle farming. The whole family is engaged in it to meet the large family’s most necessary needs. Karo’s children have musical talent and wish to attend a musical school. The only way to make the children’s dreams come true is to expand the business.  Karo is planning to purchase 3 cows.

loans.use: To purchase 3 cows

loans.name: Krissia Masiel

texts.es:
Krissia, es una joven de 21 años de edad, se dedica a la venta de ropa y reside en San Francisco Gotera, departamento de Morazán,  ella alquila vivienda y vive con su hijo Brandon de 3 años de edad, su negocio es la venta de ropa visitando casa por casa a sus clientes y también de forma ambulante en el centro de la ciudad, no tiene horario para salir a la venta y lo hace desde hace seis meses.
Ella solicita un préstamo para la compra de mercadería, este préstamo le ayudara a adquirir ropa de estilos de moda y tendrá la oportunidad de ofrecer más variedad a los clientes, ella espera que sus ventas le aumenten con esta inversión.
Para Krissia su sueño es tener un negocio bien establecido que le de las ganancias suficientes para dar a su hijo los cuidos necesarios y que crezca sanamente.
texts.en:
Krissia is 21 years old and works selling clothing. She lives in San Francisco Gotera, in the Morazán department. She rents housing and lives with her son Brandon, who is 3 years old. Her business is door to door sales visiting her clients and selling clothing as well as a street vendor downtown. She does not have a set schedule for selling and she has done this for the past 6 months.

She is requesting a loan to buy merchandise. This loan will help her to get fashionable clothing and she will have the opportunity to offer a greater variety to her customers. She hopes that her sales will increase with this investment. Krissia's dream is to have a well established business with sufficient earnings to provide her son with necessary care so that he can grow healthily.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha es socia del bancomunal Ccatun Saccha, tiene 29 años de edad, es casada y tiene una hija de 6 años.
Martha se dedica a la venta de prendas de vestir importadas para damas caballeros y niños, vende a los colegas de su esposo por pedidos y le pagan en partes.
El crédito que solicita lo invertirá para la compra de panteones, juguetes porcampaña navideña.
A Martha le gustan las reuniones de su bancomunal porque puede ahorrar y acceder al crédito, le gustan la capacitaciones porque le hablan de los valores, familia, matrimonio, hijos y del negocio.
Su sueño es comprarse un carro y tener su casa propia, porque por el momento vive en casa alquilada.
texts.en:
Martha is a member of the community bank Ccatun Saccha. She is 29 years old, married and has a 6 year old daughter. Martha sells imported clothing for women, men and children. She sells to her husband's colleagues and they pay for their orders in parts. 

The loan that she is requesting will be invested to buy panettones and toys because the Christmas season is approaching. Martha enjoys the community bank gatherings because she is able to save and have access to credit. She likes the members because they talk about their values, family, marriage, children, and businesses. Her dream is to buy a car and have her own home because as of now she lives in a rented house.

loans.use: Purchase of panettones and toys.

loans.name: Paix Plus Group

texts.en:
Paix Plus is a community bank of 19 owners of small businesses who selected Evelyne as chairwoman. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva through the microfinance institution (MFI) HOPE DRCongo to grow their businesses. They organized themselves by affinity and proximity.

Evelyne earns a living by selling loaves of bread in her neighborhood located southwest of Kinshasa. She has more customers. She started her business in 2000 with a beginning capital of US$50. She has already received six loans from HOPE DRC and repaid them correctly. Her business brings in a profit of US$40 each week.  

Evelyne is planning with the next loan to purchase 40 boxes of loaves of bread to resell at a profit. Her ambition is to provide loaves of bread to more than a thousand customers in the medium term. 

She is 40 years old, married and the mother of six children between the ages of 4 and 11. She is also responsible for eight other children left in her care by relatives.

loans.use: To buy 40 boxes of loaves of bread to resell at profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Norma Victoria

texts.es:
Norma es socia del bancomunal Ccatun Saccha, tiene 47 años y 6 hijos.
Norma, se dedica a la confección de mandiles, blusas, fustanes, centros, los vende en las ferias de Ayacucho, Huanta, Sachabamba, Matará, Seccelambras, aprendió a coser desde niña  con su madre y lo complemento con su esposo pues el es sastre y juntos abrieron una sastrería ahora confeccionan uniformes, ternos, mandiles, blusas y fustanes.
El crédito que solicita lo invertirá en la compras de telas, organzas, blondas e hilos.
Desde que está en Finca su vida a cambiado porque ha crecido su negocio. Lo que le gusta de las reuniones de su bancomunal es que puede ahorrar y acceder al crédito. Aprendió mucho en la capacitaciones sobre familia, matrimonio y violencia familiar.
Su sueño es que su negocio crezca y que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Norma is a member of the Ccatun Saccha communal bank.  She is 47 years old and has 6 children.
