loans.name: Lun

texts.en:
Lun K., 28, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. K. is a housewife while her husband is employed at a private company, earning an income of about USD 11 per day. K. has to spend USD 30 on food, USD 15 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 55 on other necessary expenses every month.

K. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase vegetables to start a business of selling vegetables. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy vegetables to resell.

loans.name: Felix

texts.en:
This is Felix C., 46, resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. He is married to Agrifina C., and together they mange their household and business. Presently, they are both working hard to provide finances for their everyday expenses.

Felix operates a frozen food business. He buys frozen cuts of meat and spiced hams, native sausages, sweetened and cured meat, and others of the like. He then adds a small amount on the selling price, sells them on credit for one week, and then earns his profits a week later. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a Php15,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products to expand his product inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.  

Felix dreams of being able to have his house renovated by the end of the year. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products to expand his product inventory.

loans.name: Bienvinida

texts.en:
Bienvinida G. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Tagbak, Brgy. Hilub-ang, Calatrava, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  pig fattening and farming. Her husband, Francisco G., who is 55 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have ten children who are between 8 and 30 years old.

Bienvinida joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Bienvinida has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,500, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to buy feed and fertilizers for the farm so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of business. Bienvinida G. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
This is Yolanda G., 53, resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She is already widowed is working hard to continually provide income for her family’s everyday expenses.

Yolanda manages her own farm. She mostly grows seasonal crops which she then sells to the local markets. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php2,000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php28,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more supplies for the farm like fertilizers, seedlings and other products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Yolanda dreams of being able to buy her own delivery vehicle, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.name: Modesto

texts.en:
This is Modesto D. S.. He's a resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. He is 42 years old and a proud worker in his own business.

Modesto operates a fruit and vegetable stand. He buys seasonal fruits that are native to the Philippines like pineapples, which are grown mostly in the south region of Luzon. He also sells green and ripe mangoes, melons, watermelons, and other Filipino fruit staples. Also in his product inventory are garlic and onions, tomatoes and other staples for simple cooking recipes. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of 200 Philippines pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of fruit and vegetables to expand his product inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.
  
Modesto dreams to be able to have his house renovated by the end of the year. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buy more quantities of fruit and vegetables to expand his product inventory

loans.name: Mary Dave Ann

texts.en:
Mary Dave Ann is from the village of Danao. She is 22 years old. To make a living, Mary Dave Ann owns & operates a business venture selling fish in the local community. Mary Dave Ann has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Mary Dave Ann has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. Mary Dave Ann is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Mary Dave Ann from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Neicy

texts.en:
Neicy M. is from the village of Brgy. Sta. Maria, Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 38 years old. Neicy is single. To make a living, Neicy owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Neicy has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Neicy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Neicy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Neicy is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Neicy from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Delchie

texts.en:
Mrs. Delchie F. is from the villlage of Baybay, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. She is 31 years old, married to Ludivindo F. and blessed with 2 children of whom one is now school-aged and the other is still an infant. To make a living, she is presently engaged in gasoline retailing business.. They’re earning an average amount of not less than Php 3,000 from this kind of business. 

Just this year, Delchie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  As a newly recognized member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program, Delchie has successfully repaid a loan amount of P 5,000. She is now requesting a loan of Php 15,000 as her 2nd loan which will be used as additional capital for her gasoline retailing business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, making loan repayments, paying for children’s education and possible business expansion.

Pring N., 64, is widowed and resides with her two children in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat temple. N. is a housewife while two of her children are employed at a casino in the town, earning an income of about USD 100 each per month. N. has to spend USD 50 on food, USD 5 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 25 on other necessary expenses every month.

N. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for the family's use.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna T. is from the village of Poblacion, Concepcion. She is 39 years old, married, and blessed with one school-aged child. Myrna is engaged in the food sector, specifically in food vending (carenderia). From this activity, she's able to earn a monthly net income of 3,200 PHP. She has been in her business for 2 years.

In 2010, Myrna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna is requesting her 1st loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used as working capital for the business.  

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional working capital for the business.

loans.name: Ek

texts.en:
Ek Y., 39, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat temple. Y. raises pigs to sell, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. Her husband is employed repairing temples, earning an income of about USD 6.17 per day. Y. has to spend USD 50 on food, USD 5 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 20 on other necessary expenses every month.

Y. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a plot of farmland to grow more rice. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland to grow more rice.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn D. is from the village of Lower Salug Dako Mahayag ZDS. She is 33 years old.

Analyn is an individual member of PMPC. To make a living, Analyn owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from her piggery. Analyn has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Analyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analyn is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Analyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional capital to buy piglets.

loans.name: Dam

texts.en:
Dam M., 43, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat temple. M. raises pigs to sell, earning an income of about USD 5 per day. Her husband buys cows to resell, earning an income of about USD 5 per day. M. has to spend USD 25 on food, USD 5 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 10 on other necessary expenses every month.

M. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase cows to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. M.'s husband appears in the photograph because M. is not available.

loans.use: To buy cows to resell.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta B. is from the village of Salimpuno, Sapang Dalaga. She is 54 years old, and married with 4 adult children. To have a source of income, Julieta engaged in running a grocery store, particularly in selling basic household items. She has been in her business for 10 years and earns a monthly income of 3,000 PHP.

In 2005, Julieta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase stocks to sell. Julieta is requesting her 10th loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used as additional working capital.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for the store.

loans.name: Noun

texts.en: Noun S. is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two young children in Takeo province. She raises pigs, typically making US$1.50 of profit each day. Her husband works with his partner making and selling shoes, earning US$3 a day. Noun S. is asking for a loan of US$600 for her husband to invest with his partner for making shoes.

loans.use: To purchase shoe materials.

loans.name: Phorn's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phorn V. is a 28-year-old married woman selected as the group leader of this four-member loan. They all reside in Kong Noy village in Kandal Province and hope to improve their family living conditions with the loans.

Mrs. Phorn V. is a seamstress in a garment factory, while her husband, Mr. Hun Phearom is a bodyguard. She would like to ask for a loan to buy a wardrobe for home use.

loans.use: To buy a wardrobe for home use

loans.name: Set

texts.en:
Set S., 33, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than one dollar each day. She has been farming since 1998. Her husband is on staff at an electricity supply company. He earns US$3.50 per day. This couple has two young children living at home to support.

Set S. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. This will reduce transportation costs and allow the family to save more.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Yan

texts.en:
Yan L., 30, is a professional silk weaver living in Takeo province. She has been weaving silk scarves since 2005 and is able to make about US$2 of profit each day. Her husband is a construction foreman, typically making US$2.50 everyday. This couple has four children and three are in school.

Yan L. would like to take out a loan of US$600 to purchase more silk.

loans.use: To purchase more silk.

loans.name: Miss. Huoy Chhuon Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Miss Huoy C., who was born in 1987, is the village bank president selected by the 13 people who comprise this village bank loan. All residents of Trong Phum village in Takeo Province, the members will use their portion of the loan to improve their family living conditions.

Huoy, who is single in a five-member household, owns a two-hectare plot of land upon which she grows rice to sell to support her family; she is also a pig breeder. Huoy is requesting a loan in order to improve the yield of her rice field.

loans.use: To increase yield of her rice field

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem Y., 50, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. Since 2008, she has been selling cakes, vegetables, and meat and is able to make about US$2.50 of profit each day. She uses the trailer attached to a motorbike to transport the food and sell around the village. Her husband works in construction, making US$2.50 a day as well. This couple has four children. Two are in school and the other two are working in construction. Hem Y. wants to buy a motorbike for her children to commute to work. By buying a motorbike, her family can save more because they will not have to spend money on moto-taxis.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Nop

texts.en: Nop K., 24, lives with her husband and one young child in Takeo province. Since 1998, she has been working at the farm growing rice and is able to make about US$1.50 each day. Her husband is a construction foreman, earning US$5 per day. Nop K. would like to take out a loan of US$300 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Nop

texts.en: Nop K., 32, is married with two young children living at home in Takeo province. To earn living, she sells cakes and desserts, making US$3 per day. Her husband is a car driver at a private company. He makes US$5 every day. Nop K. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: In's Group

texts.en:
The 13 members of this village loan all live in Traeuy Troeng village in Kandal Province. This group selected Mrs. In T., 63 years old, as the village bank president. All members will use their portion of the loan to support their individual purposes.

Mrs. In T., a farmer who owns a plot of land upon which she cultivates rice for a living, alS. raises pigs for sale. She is requesting a loan to support both of these ventures as well as to purchase fishnets for the fishing business of her husband, Hor Hao, who alS. alS. helps in his wife's businesses. This couple has a child who works as a knitter.

loans.use: To cultivate rice and raise pigs

loans.name: Chhoun

texts.en: Chhoun S. is 35 years old and lives with her husband and one young child in the Takeo province. She is a garment factory worker, making US$2.50 every day. Her husband, pictured here, is a moto-taxi driver. On average, he makes US$3 of profit a day. Chhoun S. wants to take out a loan of US$800 to replace an old and unreliable motorbike for her husband.

loans.use: To replace an old motorbike.

loans.name: Shu's Group

texts.en:
The group for this loan consists of four people. They are located in Preaek Ta Pov village, Kandal province.  This group selected Mrs. Shu M., a 30 year old, married woman, as the group leader. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Shu M. earns her living by selling fish in the market. Since her fish selling is going well, she wants to expand it. So she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fish to help expand her business. Her husband, Mr. Thab Saly, is 32 years old and works as a construction worker. With their businesses, they are able to earn some income to support their three children. Two are attending the local school and the youngest one is 2 years old.

loans.use: To buy more fish to expand the business

loans.name: Epifania

texts.en:
This is Epifania B., 60, resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She has five children, two of whom are already enrolled in college, while three stay at home managing the household and helping her with the business. By the grace of God, Epifania has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Epifania operates a computer rental shop. In the Philippines, very few people own their own computers. Thus there is a need for them, especially for students who need to do their research and papers. She rents out computers by the hour and offers printing and typing services. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php250 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more hardware and software needed for the shop. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Epifania dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more hardware and software needed for the shop.

loans.name: Chhin's Group

texts.en:
Four people have formed a group to get a loan. They are located in Preaek Reang village in Kandal province. This group selected Mrs. Chhin V., a 32 year old, married woman, as the group leader. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Chhin V. earns her living through selling vegetables in the market. Her husband, Mr. Yun Yim, is 32 years old and works as a construction worker. With their careers, they are able to earn some income to support their family. In order to increase income to improve the family condition, Mrs. Chhin V. decided to ask for a loan to purchase a sewing machine for her use. With the rest of the loan, she would buy more vegetables to support her vegetable-selling business. 

Mrs. Chhin V. is a mother of two children. One is attending the local school and another is 5 years old and not yet in school.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en:
This is Cheryl A., 40, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Leonardo, a pedicab driver, and together they have a child who helps her with the business. By the grace of God, Cheryl has managed to support her child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Cheryl operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piecemeal rates. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Cheryl dreams of being able to finish college education of her children with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Sum's Group

texts.en:
Five members are forming a group loan. They are located in Chrolong village in Kandal province. This group selected Mr. Sum M., 30 years old, as the group leader. With the loan, the members of this group hope to increase income to improve each of their family’s condition. 

Mr. Sum M. is a farmer who owns a rice field plot and cultivates rice for a living. He would like to ask for a loan to support his farm crop. Aside from farming, Mr. Sum M. is also a construction worker. His wife, Mrs. Tep Kunthea, is 29 years old and works as a seamstress in the garment factory. With their occupations they are able to earn some income to support their three children: two are attending the local school and the youngest one is 2 years old.

loans.use: To support his rice crop

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
This is Aurora O., 64, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Remigio O., and together with their child, they manage the household and the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Aurora operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piecemeal rates.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php18,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
 
Aurora dreams of being able to improve their business and having a comfortable and happy life for her family forever. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Tin's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Tin S. is a 32 year old married woman, and she has been selected the group leader by its four members.  She and her spouse have three children: two are attending the local school and the last one is 5 years old and not in school yet. 

They are located in Tboung Kdei village in Kandal province.  Each member of this village group will use their portion of the loan to support a different purpose.  
 
Mrs. Tin S. earns her living by selling fish in the market.  Her husband, Mr. Yung Van Chum, 35 years old, works as a car mechanic.  With their occupations, they still do not earn enough income to support the family.  In order to increase their income and improve the family condition, Mrs. Tin S. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets for raise for sale.

loans.use: To buy piglets for raise for sale.

loans.name: Chet

texts.en:
Mrs. Chet T. is 39 and is a married woman who lives in the province of Kompong Cham. This family earns an average of $6.50 per day. They have three children, and all of them are single. Two of them are studying in public school, while the other one works in the factory as a garment worker, and has a proper salary every month. Mrs. Chet T. is a local farmer, and her husband assists her in the farming business also. Mrs. Chet T. grows different kinds of crops such as rice and cucumbers on her farmland, and they are growing well.

Mrs. Chet T. thinks that it is a good time for making additional income to support her family's expenses. So she would like to request a loan to purchase more cucumbers for planting, and to pay the plowing fee.

loans.use: To purchase more cucumbers for planting, and to pay plowing fee.

loans.name: Ung's Group

texts.en: This loan group consists of four members in Barku village in Kandal province. This group selected Mrs. Ung M., born in 1969, as the group leader. Each member of the group will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Ung M. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from farming, she is also rice middleman to earn additional profits to support her family. In order to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions, she would like a loan to buy more rice and grow her current business. Mrs. Ung M. is a widow with a child who helps her in the business.

loans.use: to buy more rice to sell.

loans.name: Jargalsaikhan

texts.en: Mr. Jargalsaikhan, 32 years old, lives with his wife and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic tent. In 2005, he started a taxi business using a car which he bought with a loan from KIVA. This is his fifth loan through Credit Mongol. He has gained a lot of experience over the years. Two of his children attend a local secondary school and the third goes to kindergarten. His wife operates a diner near by his home. Jargalsaikhan is a very busy person who says: "as a father I would like to be financially able to provide a good education and other necessary expenses for my children." He is requesting a 1.500.000 MNT loan to purchase construction materials to build a garage in his yard.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials to build a garage.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
The two people shown in the picture are Mrs. Chan C. and her husband. Mrs. Chan C., 31 years old, is a humble mother who has two young children who attend school. Mrs. Chan C. cultivates rice and vegetables on her farmland that she inherited from her grandparents. Her husband also works with her on the farm.

 Beside the current farm work, Mrs. Chan C. has feeds some pigs behind her house in order to earn extra income. Because the pig-raising business is a very profitable one for Mrs. Chan C. and her family, she has requested a loan in order to buy additional pigs to fatten for sale.

loans.use: To buy additional pigs to raise for sale

loans.name: Angeliza's Group

texts.en:
Angeliza S. is from the village of Brgy. Sta.Cruz, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 48 years old. Angeliza is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Angeliza is married and has 3 children. To make a living, Angeliza owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Angeliza has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Angeliza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angeliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Angeliza is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Angeliza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 55 years old, married, and father of six, aged between 10-30 years, with two attending school.  He has been a mixed farmer for twenty years.  He sells bananas, maize, beans, sugarcane, coffee and milk locally.

He has requested this loan of Kshs. 45,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. The proceeds will cater for school fees and other family expenses.  In five years he aspires to have four dairy cows.

The challenge he is facing is unpredictable weather occurrences affecting  crop production, e.g., tomatoes.   He is thankful to Juhudi for the loan and hopes to get more later on.

loans.use: buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Jovinsol's Group

texts.en:
Jovinsol C. is from the village of Brgy.Bonfal East, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 32 years old. Jovinsol is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Jovinsol is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jovinsol owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling fish balls and other dimsums to the local community. Jovinsol has been engaged in his business for over 12 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jovinsol joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovinsol has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jovinsol is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Jovinsol from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

location.town: Brgy. Bonfal East, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Abel

texts.en:
Abel is 48 years old, married, and the father of four, aged between 14-18 years, all attending school.  He has been practicing  mixed farming for more than ten years.  He produces maize, tea leaves, tomatoes, onions and beans which he sells locally.

He has requested this loan of Kshs. 55,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow. Extra income earned from this loan will support the family financially and improve their living standard.  In five years he hopes to have five cows producing at least 30 litres of milk a day.
 
The challenges he is faces are changes in weather, seasons, and lack of a ready market for his produce.  He is thankful to Juhudi for helping him improve financially.

loans.use: buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Zayrakan

texts.en:
Zayrakan K. is 54 and has eight children; seven are grown and live on their own, and the youngest son studies at school.  Her husband Jamanak worked at the local school for 37 years as a teacher of mathematics and now is on pension. 

More than 20 years ago, in order to find a means of subsistence for their large family, Zayrakan with her husband decided to engage in livestock breeding, with the initial sum of 16,000 Kyrgyz Soms.  With the revenue, they were able to give a good education to all of their children.  In spite of all expenses of the large family, they managed to expand their herd of cattle and today Zayrakan’s farm has four milch cows, thirty sheep, ten goats and two horses. 

Zayrakan wants to use this loan of 100,000 KGS to buy more cattle. With the revenue from this loan, Zayrakan plans to reconstruct a barn for her cattle to provide good conditions of cattle maintenance.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 40 yrs old. She is married and the mother of four, aged between 6 and 23 years, all attending school. She has been practising mixed farming  for the last ten years.  She sells vegetables, maize, beans and tomatoes in the local market. She has two casual employees.

She has requested this loan of Kshs. 50,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to expand her tomato farming and cereal produces. This will earn her income to support her family.  In five years she hopes to have at least four dairy cows for milk production.

Her two main challenges are lack of a ready market for the products and poor the transport network.

loans.use: Expand tomato farming & cereal products

loans.name: Nyakwara

texts.en:
Nyakwara is 76 years old, married, and the father of fourteen, aged between 5 and 62 years, with three attending school.  He has been a mixed farmer for fifty years and sells maize, beans, bananas, coffee and milk locally.

He has requested a loan of Kshs. 45,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow. Extra income from this loan will assist him in  paying school fees for the children. In five years he aspires to have a posho (cornmeal) mill.

The challenge he is facing is lack of enough capital to purchase farming inputs like fertilizers hence affecting crop production.  He is thankful to Juhudi and promises to continue to fight against poverty.

loans.use: buy a cow

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en:
Damaris is 38 years old, married and the mother of four, aged between 10 and 22 years, all attending school.  She has been a mixed farmer for twenty years. She has one employee. Her products are maize, millet, milk and chickens which she sells locally.

She has requested this loan of Kshs. 30,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow. Income generated from this loan  will cater for the children's school fees.  In five years she aspires to acquire a plot of land to build both a house and rental business.

The challenge she faces is poor road infrastructure and low market prices for the milk.  She thanks Juhudi for introducing loan facilities to her.

loans.use: buy a cow

loans.name: Ruperto

texts.en:
Mr. Ruperto D. is from the Barangay of Digson, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. He is 37 years old, and still single. To make a living, he is presently connected with San Miguel Food Inc. as driver/salesman. He’s been engaged in this kind of job for 6 years. He is earning an average amount of not less than Php12,000.00 as his basic monthly salary. 

Just this year, Ruperto joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruperto as a newly recognized member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program is now requesting a loan of Php40,000.00 as his 1st loan which will be used for purchasing housing materials for his ongoing house construction/renovation.

 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: San

texts.en: San Y. has been a farmer for many years. She and her husband live in the province of Kompong Cham. San Y. cultivates rice from which she makes a daily income. On average, she makes US$2.50 of profit a day. San Y. is married and has no children. Currently, she also raises pigs to make additional income in order to support her family's needs.  San Y. would like to use her loan to purchase more pigs to raise for selling and to use the remainder of the loan to buy cucumber seeds for planting.

texts.en:
Quennie M. is from the town of Leon B. Postigo. She is 32 years old. Quennie is married. To make a living, Quennie owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of products in the local community. Quennie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Quennie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Quennie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 150,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Quennie is requesting a new loan of 50000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 12th loan taken out by Quennie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business.
